A unit containing Captain gains the following additions rules.


  • If the unit has a Standard Bearer, it is considered to be within range of its Battle Standard Bearer’s* Rally Around the Flag.

  • If the unit has a Musician, it is considered to be within range of its General’s* Commanding Presence.

A unit can only contain a single Attachable Model with Captain, but Captains with Battle Standard Bearer or General are not counted towards this.
*Provided such models are on the Battlefield at all.

rulebook-channel.title: Channel
rulebook-channel.def: During <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/siphon_the_veil">Siphon the Veil</nuxt-link>, each of the Active Player’s <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">models</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/channel">Channel</nuxt-link> adds X <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/magic_dice">Magic Dice</nuxt-link> to their owner’s <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/magic_dice">Magic Dice</nuxt-link> pool.

rulebook-commanding_presence.title: Commanding Presence
rulebook-commanding_presence.def:
If any friendly unit is within 12" of the model:


  • Its Courage is set to the Courage of the model with Commanding Presence, unless their original value is higher.


Apply any modifiers to the model’s Courage first, then set the recipient model’s Courage to that value. No single source of modifiers are applied more than once.


  • It gains Disciplined, if the model with Commanding Presence has it.

If the model with Commanding Presence is Shaken, this rule cannot be used.
If rules, properties or unit names are mentioned in brackets following this rule (X), it means that only units possessing these qualities can benefit from the model’s Commanding Presence.

rulebook-deafening_clamour.title: Deafening Clamour
rulebook-deafening_clamour.def: Enemy units within 12" cannot use <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/musician">Musician</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-dying_blow.title: Dying Blow
rulebook-dying_blow.def: When a model with Dying Blow is about to be removed during any Agility Step of a Round of Combat it is fighting, remove it instead as a casualty only at the end of Agility Step 0.

rulebook-engineer.title: Engineer
rulebook-engineer.def:
Once during each Shooting Phase, a non-Shaken model with Engineer can select a friendly model with X in a unit within 6" of it, and choose one of the following:


  • Repair: Roll a D6. If the score is equal or higher than the chosen model’s Resilience, it Recovers 1 HP.

  • Calibrate: The chosen model gains Accurate, and for the purpose of rolling to hit using the Artillery rule, all targets are considered to be of Height 5. Note that the usage of this must be declared before rolling to hit.

rulebook-exclusive.title: Exclusive
rulebook-exclusive.def:
This rule limits which Attachable Model is allowed to join what unit.


  • Attachable Models with Exclusive (X) can only join units containing X.

  • Non-Attachable Models with Exclusive (X) can only be joined by Attachable Models.

  • Models with Exclusive without brackets cannot join units or be joined by other models at all.

The specific criteria for X can include unit names, Model Rules, or upgrades.

If a model has both Exclusive and Attached, apply all requirements from both rules. In some cases, this may mean the model cannot be deployed. In this case, the model is considered a casualty.

rulebook-fearless.title: Fearless
rulebook-fearless.def: A unit containing Fearless automatically passes Panic Tests, cannot choose Flee! as a Charge Reaction unless it’s already Shaken, and ignores the effects of Horror.

rulebook-feigned_flight.title: Feigned Flight
rulebook-feigned_flight.def:
At the end of a Combat, before rolling any Break Tests, any unit with Feigned Flight may choose to voluntarily break from the Combat. If so, the unit is considered to have failed a Break Test. If the unit was on the winning side of the combat, the enemy cannot Pursue.

In addition, any Rally Tests taken by units with Feigned Flight after voluntarily becoming Shaken (either due to Charge Reaction Flee! or disengaging from combat), are automatically passed. This cannot be used if the unit has performed another Flee move before rolling the Rally Test.

Models with Fearless and Feigned Flight are not prevented from choosing Charge Reaction Flee! due to Fearless.

Remember that a voluntary Flee Move does not cause a Panic Test in friendly units that the Fleeing unit moves through.

rulebook-fly.title: Fly
rulebook-fly.def:
Units with Fly ignore Terrain Features and other units during Move Manoeuvres and Charge Moves. The unit must however follow the Unit Spacing rule at the end of its moves, and Terrain Features from which the model starts or ends its move still affect it.
During a Charge Move, the charged unit is not ignored, and there must be room for the unit’s Front Facing to be placed in contact with the charged unit before the Align Move.

rulebook-frenzy.title: Frenzy
rulebook-frenzy.def: Units containing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/frenzy">Frenzy</nuxt-link> must always choose to Pursue, when able to.

rulebook-ghost_step.title: Ghost Step
rulebook-ghost_step.def:
A unit with Ghost Step ignores Terrain Features when moving. The unit must however follow the Unit Spacing rule at the end of its move.

If the unit ends a move inside Impassable Terrain, backtrack the move to the unit’s last legal position, unless as part of a Flee Move, in which case the standard Flee Moves rules apply.

rulebook-afflict.title: Afflict
rulebook-afflict.def:
Units in contact with one or more enemy models with Afflict (X), suffer the effects given by X.
Note that this means that each unit can only be affected by one instance of each Afflict (X), provided that the X in brackets is identical. If the brackets from two instances of Afflict confer different effects, i.e. different X, then these are considered different rules are the effects from both rules are applied.

rulebook-hidden.title: Hidden
rulebook-hidden.def:
The model isn’t deployed as normal. Instead, at the start of any Player Turn, the owner can choose a friendly unit containing Rank-and-File models, that satisfy the following:


  • The model with Hidden could have joined the unit.

  • The model with Hidden has an identical Base Size and Height as the Rank-and-File models in the unit.

  • The unit isn’t Shaken, and isn’t a Summoned unit.

After choosing an eligible unit, follow these steps:


  • Remove a Rank-and-File model with the same base size as the model with Hidden from the front rank from the chosen unit as a casualty.

  • Deploy the model with Hidden where the removed model was positioned.

rulebook-insignificant.title: Insignificant
rulebook-insignificant.def: Units with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/insignificant">Insignificant</nuxt-link> don’t cause <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/panic_tests">Panic Tests</nuxt-link> on units not containing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/insignificant">Insignificant</nuxt-link> when making <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/flee_move">Flee Moves</nuxt-link> through them.

rulebook-light_troops.title: Light Troops
rulebook-light_troops.def:
Units with Light Troops cannot perform Advance Moves or March Moves, and when they perform Reform Moves, the centre of the unit can move up to twice the unit’s Mobility (rather than as normal only half Mobility). Depending on how far the centre of the unit has moved during a Reform Move (the straight path from starting to ending position), additional rules apply:


  • If further than the unit’s Mobility, the move is considered a March Move for the purpose of triggering Dangerous Terrain tests, and for units such as Undead being restricted from performing March Move. Note that for the purpose of Shooting, this is still considered a Reform Move.

Units containing Light Troops are always considered to have 0 Proper Ranks. Ignore Attachable Models with Light Troops joined to a unit for this, unless the unit consists of only Attachable Models.

rulebook-magic_resistance.title: Magic Resistance
rulebook-magic_resistance.def: When an enemy <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> casts a spell that targets a unit containing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/magic_resistance">Magic Resistance</nuxt-link>, the Casting Roll of the spell is decreased by X.

rulebook-meetingofminds.title: Meeting of Minds
rulebook-meetingofminds.def: The model gains Scent of Blood and treats all friendly models with Beast as Insignificant.

rulebook-protean_magic.title: Protean Magic
rulebook-protean_magic.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> knows X <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/spells">spells</nuxt-link>. It doesn’t choose a Path of Magic, instead it can select Apprentice <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/spells">Spells</nuxt-link> from the Paths available to it. The choice of <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/spells">spells</nuxt-link> is written on the Army List. During <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/pregame_selections">Pre-game Selections</nuxt-link>, the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> can swap one spell for the Hereditary Spell in the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model’s</nuxt-link> Armybook.

rulebook-rally_around_the_flag.title: Rally Around the Flag
rulebook-rally_around_the_flag.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Models</nuxt-link> within 12" of a friendly non-Shaken <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/rally_around_the_flag">Rally Around the Flag</nuxt-link> must reroll failed <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/courage_tests">Courage Tests</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-random_movement.title: Random Movement
rulebook-random_movement.def:
Units with Random Movement do not follow normal rules for Charging, Move Manoeuvres, Pursue Moves or Flee Moves. Instead, apply the following:


  • During the Charge Phase, the model cannot Declare any Charges.

  • It must perform a move in the movement phase.

  • At any time the model would perform a Move Manoeuvre, the unit performs a Pursue Move (see Melee chapter) with the following exceptions:

  • It moves the distance stated in brackets (X).

  • It can choose which direction it will move in. The owning player must choose which direction before rolling the Pursuit Distance.

  • It does not take Dangerous Terrain Tests unless Charging.

  • It can only Charge units that were in its Front Arc before the pivot.

Treat units outside the Front Arc as obstacles.




  • Note that this means a model with Random Movement cannot perform Magical Moves or use Vanguard.





  • The model’s Pursue and Flee moves use the distance stated in brackets (X), instead of the normal rules.

Whenever a rule requires the Mobility or Charge Speed of the model, use the potential maximum value of X.

rulebook-scout.title: Scout
rulebook-scout.def:
Units with Scout are not required to be deployed inside their Deployment Zone. They may be deployed anywhere on the Battlefield that is at least 12" away from the opponent’s deployment Zone.

A unit that starts the game outside their own Deployment Zone cannot declare a Charge in the first Player Turn of the first Game Turn.

rulebook-skirmisher.title: Skirmisher
rulebook-skirmisher.def:
Units containing Skirmisher adopt a skirmish formation when forming a unit. Instead of being in contact with each other, these models are placed 12.5mm apart (roughly half an inch, see the figure below). These gaps between the models are considered part of the unit for Cover purposes, and it has the same Height as the models. Other than this gap between models, units with Skirmisher follow the normal rules for forming units and therefore have a Front, two Flanks, and a Rear Facing, can perform Supporting Attacks, and so on.

Units in Skirmish formation can only be joined by Attachable Models that have the same Height as the unit. Unless an Attachable Model has the exact same base size as all Rank-and-File models in the unit, it is considered Mismatched for the purpose of placement within the unit.

The unit ceases to be in Skirmish formation when all models with Skirmisher have been removed. When this happens, immediately contract their skirmish formation into a normal formation, without moving the centre of the first rank. Nudge any unit as normal to maintain contact if Engaged in Combat.

See figure Figure X: Skirmish formation.
An example of a unit in Skirmish formation with a joined Mismatching Character. All models are 12.5 mm away from each other.
The same unit Engaged in Combat. Only darkened models may attack. Models with a dashed frame can attack a Character (either C1 or C2). Models with a lighter shade cannot attack at all.

rulebook-stand_behind.title: Stand Behind
rulebook-stand_behind.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attachable_models">Attachable Models</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/stand_behind">Stand Behind</nuxt-link> are not required to have their Front Facing as far forward as possible within their unit. Essentially this means that the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> can be positioned anywhere within its unit. This rule cannot be used while the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> has a mismatching base to its unit.

rulebook-strider.title: Strider
rulebook-strider.def:
Models with Strider may ignore rules associated with Terrain Features, with the following exceptions:


  • Any rule affecting Line of Sight or Cover.

  • Any rule associated with Weakness.

Occasionally, Strider is associated with a specific type of Terrain, which would be indicated in brackets (X). In such cases, Strider only affects this particular Terrain Feature.

rulebook-stubborn.title: Stubborn
rulebook-stubborn.def:
When a unit containing Stubborn loses a combat, the modifier to the Courage from the Combat Score difference is halved, rounding fractions up (i.e. towards a larger modifier). Note that if the unit is also Steady, the modifier is first set to no smaller than 3 following the Steady rules, and then halved, rounding up, to 2.

If the unit is Unstable, the Health Point losses due to Unstable are halved, rounding fractions up (i.e. towards more Health Point losses).

rulebook-supernal.title: Supernal
rulebook-supernal.def:
When a unit with Supernal fails a Break Test, instead of being Broken and subsequently Shaken, it suffers a number of Health Point losses equal to the amount by which the combat was lost, with no saves of any kind allowed.

These Health Point losses are first allocated towards Rank-and-File models, and once enough Health Points losses are suffered to remove all Rank-and-File models, remaining Health Point losses are allocated by the owner towards Attachable Models, as evenly as possible.

Attachable Models with Supernal can only join units containing Supernal, and units containing Supernal can only be joined by Attachable Models with Supernal.

rulebook-swiftstride.title: Swiftstride
rulebook-swiftstride.def: Rolls for range on <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/charge_range">Charge Range</nuxt-link>, Flee Distance and Pursue Distance by units with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/swiftstride">Swiftstride</nuxt-link> are all subject to Maximised Roll.

rulebook-terror.title: Terror
rulebook-terror.def: When a unit containing Terror declares a Charge, the target must take a Panic Test. If the test is failed, the unit must choose Flee! as its Charge Reaction if allowed to do so (e.g. not already Engaged in Combat). Note that this Flee Move is not considered voluntary, and thus friendly units that may be required to take a Panic Test when moving through them. Units containing Terror are immune to the effects of Terror.

rulebook-undead.title: Undead
rulebook-undead.def:
Units containing Undead cannot perform March Moves unless the unit is within range of a friendly model’s Commanding Presence.

Models with Undead have an additional characteristic called Resurrect (Rsr) on their statline. Whenever a Health Pool with a Resurrect value is about to Raise or Recover a Health Point, it instead Raises or Recovers an amount of Health Points equal to its Resurrect value.

rulebook-unruly.title: Unruly
rulebook-unruly.def: Command Tests taken by a unit containing Unruly are passed on 5+. If a unit contains both Unruly and Musician, the rules cancel each other out (which normally means Command Tests are passed on 4+).

rulebook-unstable.title: Unstable
rulebook-unstable.def:
When a unit with Unstable would take a Break Test, instead it suffers a number of Health Point losses equal to the amount by which the combat was lost, with no saves of any kind allowed.

These Health Point losses are first allocated towards Rank-and-File models, and once enough Health Points losses are suffered to remove all Rank-and-File models, remaining Health Point losses are allocated by the owner towards Attachable Models, as evenly as possible.

The Health Point losses can be reduced in the following ways:


  • Remember that if the unit has Stubborn, the Health Point losses are halved, rounding fractions up.

  • If the unit is affected by Rally Around the Flag, reduce the Health Point loss by 1.

  • If the unit is Steady while affected by Rally Around the Flag, reduce the Health Point loss by an additional 1.

  • If the unit is Steadfast while affected by Rally Around the Flag, reduce the Health Point loss by an additional 1.

I.e. a unit that is affected by Rally Around the Flag while being Steadfast reduces the Health Point losses by a total of 3.

Attachable Models with Unstable can only join units containing Unstable, and units containing Unstable can only be joined by Attachable Models with Unstable.

rulebook-vanguard.title: Vanguard
rulebook-vanguard.def:
After deployment, units with Vanguard may perform an out of sequence Move Manoeuvre (Reform, Advance, or March Move), with the following exceptions:


  • If an X is given, the unit’s Mobility is set to always X" during this move.

  • No model can move further than 12" during this move, regardless of its Mobility.

  • It cannot move within 6" of an enemy unit.

  • Attachable Models cannot leave a unit as part of this move.

If both players have units with Vanguard, they alternate moving units one by one, starting with the player that finished deploying first.

A unit that starts the game outside their own Deployment Zone cannot declare a Charge in the first Player Turn of the first Game Turn.

rulebook-warplatform.title: WarPlatform
rulebook-warplatform.def:
The model follows the rules for Attachable Models, with the following exceptions:


  • If can never perform Make Way moves, not even if it is also a Character.

  • For the purpose of allocating Ranged Attacks onto a unit with a WarPlatform joined to it, the model with WarPlatform is considered to be the same Height as the largest group of other Rank-and-File models in the same unit. If there are no other Rank-and-File models in the unit, ignore this rule.

  • Only a single model with WarPlatform can be joined to the same unit.

When the model is joined to a unit, its Mobility and Charge Speed is set to that of its unit, applying the following restrictions:


  • If there are no Rank-and-File models from the unit in contact with the WarPlatform’s both flank Facings (right and left side), the model must use its own Mobility and Charge Speed instead Meaning that, if slower than the unit, the unit’s Mobility and Charge Speed are set to those of the WarPlatform.

  • The WarPlatform cannot use the unit’s Mobility and Charge Speed values when leaving the unit, including charging out of it. Instead, it uses its own Mobility and Charge Speed.

rulebook-wizard_apprentice.title: Wizard Apprentice
rulebook-wizard_apprentice.def: The model knows 1 spell, which is the Apprentice Spell (#1) of the Path it has selected. Note that the choice of Path and spells are written on the Army List, and that during Pre-game Selections, the model can swap one spell for the Hereditary Spell in the model’s Armybook.

rulebook-wizard_adept.title: Wizard Adept
rulebook-wizard_adept.def: The model gains Channel (1) and knows 3 spells, chosen from the Apprentice Spell and the Adept Spells (#1 - #4) of the Path it has selected. Note that the choice of Path and spells are written on the Army List, and that during Pre-game Selections, the model can swap one spell for the Hereditary Spell in the model’s Armybook.

rulebook-wizard_master.title: Wizard Master
rulebook-wizard_master.def: The model gains Channel (2) and knows 4 spells, chosen from the Apprentice Spell, and the Adept and Master Spells (#1 - #6) of the Path it has selected. Note that the choice of Path and spells are written on the Army List, and that during Pre-game Selections, the model can swap one spell for the Hereditary Spell in the model’s Armybook.

rulebook-wizard_conclave.title: Wizard Conclave
rulebook-wizard_conclave.def: When deploying the unit, choose one model in the unit with Wizard Conclave as the Conduit. This choice can be changed at the start of your Magic Phase. The Conduit knows X spells, and if X is 2 or larger it also gains Channel (1). The spells are chosen for the whole unit (i.e. changing Conduit does not change the spells known), are written on the Army List, and are chosen from the list of available spells listed in the Unit Entry. Note that Wizard Conclaves cannot swap spells for the Hereditary spell.

rulebook-mindless.title: Mindless
rulebook-mindless.def: A unit with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/mindless">Mindless</nuxt-link> automatically passes its <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/command_tests">Command tests</nuxt-link> for Restraining Pursuit and for Combat Reforming, and automatically fails its <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/command_tests">Command Tests</nuxt-link> for Redirecting Charges.

rulebook-emplacement.title: Emplacement
rulebook-emplacement.def:
Units with Emplacement cannot Declare Charges, perform March Moves or Pursue Moves, or choose the Flee! Charge Reaction. If a unit with Emplacement is about to perform a Flee Move, it is instead removed as a Casualty. The model cannot shoot in the same Player Turn that it performed an Advance Move or Reform Move.
Units with Emplacement can draw Line of Sight in any direction and are not limited by their Front Arc.

rulebook-not_a_hero.title: Not a Hero
rulebook-not_a_hero.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> does not suffer from Restricted <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> if it Refuses a Duel.

rulebook-aegis.title: Aegis
rulebook-aegis.def:
Aegis is a Special Save, with a value indicated in brackets (X). If X is given as a modifier and with a maximum value (e.g. +2), the model gains this as a modifier to all its Aegis Special Save rolls. A natural roll of ‘1’ or ‘2’ is always a failure. If the model doesn’t have Aegis, it instead gains a Aegis (7 X+). For example, a model without Aegis that gains Aegis (+2) will gain Aegis (5+).

Note that Aegis Saves cannot be taken against attacks with the Divine Attacks Attack Attribute.

rulebook-distracting.title: Distracting
rulebook-distracting.def:
Melee Attacks allocated against a Health Pool with Distracting suffer X to hit, up to at worst 5+.

If a Max. Y apply this following the normal rules for limits defined in Appendix IV: The Reference Manual.

rulebook-fortitude.title: Fortitude
rulebook-fortitude.def:
Fortitude is a Special Save, with a value indicated in brackets (X).

Fortitude Saves cannot be taken against attacks with the Flaming Attacks Attack Attribute, and against attacks with Lethal Strike that roll a natural ‘6’ to wound.

rulebook-hard_target.title: Hard Target
rulebook-hard_target.def: Shooting <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> allocated against a Health Pool with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/hard_target">Hard Target</nuxt-link> suffer X to hit.

rulebook-immune.title: Immune
rulebook-immune.def: Attacks with the Attack Attributes or Properties stated in brackets (X) allocated towards the model with Immune (X) lose these Attack Attributes or Properties.

rulebook-parry.title: Parry
rulebook-parry.def:
The Defensive Skill of a model with Parry is always set to at least the Offensive Skill of the attacker.
Remember that since Parry provides a modifier to a Defensive Characteristic, this is not applicable to a Character mounted on a mount with its own Defensive Characteristic.

rulebook-resistance.title: Resistance
rulebook-resistance.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> allocated against the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model’s</nuxt-link> Health Pool must reroll successful <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/towound_rolls">to-wound rolls</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-weakness.title: Weakness
rulebook-weakness.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> allocated against the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model’s</nuxt-link> Health Pool must reroll failed <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/towound_rolls">to-wound rolls</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-melee_weapons.title: Melee Weapons
rulebook-melee_weapons.def:
1whiteblack!5
5pt

Name & Characteristics Modifiers & Model Rules
Hand Weapon All models come equipped with a Hand Weapon as their default equipment and cannot lose it. & -- & Models using a Hand Weapon alongside a Shield gain Parry. A model equipped with another Melee Weapon must use this, and cannot use its Hand Weapon.
Great Weapon & +2 Str, +2 AP, always Agi* & Two-Handed *Always strike at Agility Step 0, regardless of the wielder’s Agility.
Halberd & +1 Str, +1 AP & Two-Handed.
Lance Models on foot cannot use Lances. & Devastating Charge (+2 Str, +2 AP, +1 Agi) & --
Light Lance Models on foot cannot use Light Lances. & Devastating Charge (+1 Str, +1 AP) & --
Paired Weapons & +1 Att, +1 Off & Two-Handed. Attacks made with Paired Weapons ignore Parry.
Spear Mounted models cannot use Spears. & +1 Agi & Fight in Extra Rank, Lethal Strike (against Swiftstride)*. *Cannot be used when Charging.

Melee Combat Weapons

rulebook-great_weapon.title: Great Weapon
rulebook-great_weapon.def:
+2 Str, +2 AP, always Agi*, Two-Handed

*Always strike at Agility Step 0, regardless of the wielder’s Agility.

rulebook-hand_weapon.title: Hand Weapon
rulebook-hand_weapon.def: All models come equipped with a Hand Weapon as their default equipment and cannot lose it. & -- & Models using a Hand Weapon alongside a Shield gain Parry. A model equipped with another Melee Weapon must use this, and cannot use its Hand Weapon.

rulebook-lance.title: Lance
rulebook-lance.def: Models on foot cannot use Lances. Devastating Charge (+2 Str, +2 AP, +1 Agi)

rulebook-light_lance.title: Light Lance
rulebook-light_lance.def: Models on foot cannot use Light Lances. Devastating Charge (+1 Str, +1 AP)

rulebook-paired_weapons.title: Paired Weapons
rulebook-paired_weapons.def: +1 Att, +1 Off, Two-Handed. Attacks made with Paired Weapons ignore Parry

rulebook-spear.title: Spear
rulebook-spear.def: Mounted models cannot use Spears. +1 Agi, Fight in Extra Rank, Lethal Strike (against Swiftstride)*. *Cannot be used when Charging.

rulebook-shooting_weapons.title: Shooting Weapons
rulebook-shooting_weapons.def:
1whiteblack!5
5pt

Name & Range & Shots & Str & AP & Model Rules
Bow & 24" & 1 - 3 - 0 - Shoot in Extra Rank. The attack ignores friendly models for Line of Sight and Cover purposes.
Crossbow & 30" & 1 - 4 - 1 - Unwieldy (1).
Handgun & 24" & 1 - 4 - 2 - Unwieldy (1).
Longbow & 30" & 1 - 3 - 0 - Shoot in Extra Rank. The attack ignores friendly models for Line of Sight and Cover purposes.
Pistol & 12" & 1 - 4 - 2 - Quick to Fire, Stand and Shoot.
Throwing Weapons & 8" & 2 - as user & as user & Accurate, Quick to Fire, Stand and Shoot.
Breath Attack (X) & 6" & 2D6 - X & X & March and Shoot. Hits automatically (no to-hit roll required). The Strength, Armour Penetration, and additional Attack Attributes are defined in brackets (X).



Shooting Weapons

rulebook-bow.title: Bow
rulebook-bow.def: Range 24", Shots 1, Str 3, AP 0, Volley Fire

rulebook-longbow.title: Longbow
rulebook-longbow.def: Range 30", Shots 1, Str 3, AP 0, Volley Fire

rulebook-pistol.title: Pistol
rulebook-pistol.def: Range 12", Shots 1, Str 4, AP 2, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/quick_to_fire">Quick to Fire</nuxt-link>

rulebook-throwing_weapons.title: Throwing Weapons
rulebook-throwing_weapons.def: Range 8", Shots 2, Str as user, AP as user, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/accurate">Accurate</nuxt-link>, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/quick_to_fire">Quick to Fire</nuxt-link>

rulebook-stand_and_shoot.title: Stand and Shoot
rulebook-stand_and_shoot.def:
The model may perform an out of sequence Shooting Attack when an enemy unit has successfully performed a Charge Move into contact with the model’s unit, if the following conditions are met:


  • The model’s unit is not Engaged in Combat with any other units.

  • The enemy unit Charges the model in its unit’s Front Facing.

  • The enemy unit started the Charge further away than its Charge Speed, using the lowest Charge Speed in the unit.

rulebook-artillery.title: Artillery
rulebook-artillery.def: The attack ignores <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/tohit_modifiers">to-hit modifiers</nuxt-link> from <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/cover">Cover</nuxt-link> and Long Range, but suffers -1 to hit when targeting units that have 0 Proper Ranks, including all <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/light_troops">Light Troops</nuxt-link>. The attack gains +1 to-hit when shooting at units with enough Proper Ranks to be considered Steadfast, or when shooting at a target with Height 5.

rulebook-accurate.title: Accurate
rulebook-accurate.def: The attack doesn't suffer the 1 to-hit modifier for shooting at Long Range.

rulebook-area_attack.title: Area Attack
rulebook-area_attack.def:
Before making a Shooting Attack with Area Attack, determine the attack's Target Facing hits using the same rules as for Cover.

If the attack hits in the Front or Rear: Select up to Y different ranks of the target. If the attack hits in the Flank: Select up to Y different files of the target. For each rank or file chosen this way, the unit takes X hits, up to a maximum equal to the number of models in that rank or file. An Area Attack can’t cause more hits than the total models in the unit.

If the attack misses, reduce X and Y by 1 each for every point the hit misses by, and treat it as a hit. If the to-hit roll was a natural ‘1’, or the either X or Y is reduced to 0, this is treated as a miss. Otherwise, the attack is treated as a hit instead, with the updated X and Y values. For example, if you needed 4+ to hit with Area Attack (4×4) and rolled 2 to hit, the hit is resolved with Area Attack (2(×)2) instead.

Figure figure/area_attack illustrates examples of different variations of Area Attack.

rulebook-crush_attack.title: Crush Attack
rulebook-crush_attack.def: At the model part’s Agility Step, the model part may choose to exchange all of its Standard Melee Attacks for a single Standard Melee Attack, which has its Str set to 10, its AP set to 10, and gains Multiple Wounds (D3). This cannot be done as a Restricted Attack.

rulebook-devastating_charge.title: Devastating Charge
rulebook-devastating_charge.def: Charging model parts with Devastating Charge, or using a weapon with Devastating Charge, gains the rules and Characteristic modifiers stated in brackets. For example, a model part with Devastating Charge (+1 Str) gains +1 Str when Charging.

rulebook-divine_attacks.title: Divine Attacks
rulebook-divine_attacks.def: Aegis Saves cannot be taken against Divine Attacks.

rulebook-disciplined.title: Disciplined
rulebook-disciplined.def: Command Tests taken by a unit containing Disciplinedare subject to Maximised roll. Note that this rule interacts with Commanding Presence, see Commanding Presence for details.

rulebook-extra_support.title: Extra Support
rulebook-extra_support.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part replaces the limit on the maximum number of <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> that can be done as Restricted <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> with the value in brackets (X), or if it includes a +, increases the limit with +X.

rulebook-fight_in_extra_rank.title: Fight in Extra Rank
rulebook-fight_in_extra_rank.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Model</nuxt-link> parts with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/fight_in_extra_rank">Fight in Extra Rank</nuxt-link>, or using a weapon with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/fight_in_extra_rank">Fight in Extra Rank</nuxt-link>, can make Supporting <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> from an additional rank.

rulebook-flaming_attacks.title: Flaming Attacks
rulebook-flaming_attacks.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/fortitude">Fortitude</nuxt-link> <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/saves">Saves</nuxt-link> cannot be taken against <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/flaming_attacks">Flaming Attacks</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-lightning_attacks.title: Lightning Attacks
rulebook-lightning_attacks.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/lightning_attacks">Lightning Attacks</nuxt-link> must reroll failed <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/towound_rolls">to-wound rolls</nuxt-link> against <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">models</nuxt-link> with Metal Armour.

rulebook-fury.title: Fury
rulebook-fury.def: If the attack hits with a natural to-hit roll of ‘6’, the attack causes one additional hit usually this means it causes two hits instead of one.

rulebook-hatred.title: Hatred
rulebook-hatred.def: An attack with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/hatred">Hatred</nuxt-link> must reroll failed to-hit rolls.

rulebook-lethal_strike.title: Lethal Strike
rulebook-lethal_strike.def: An attack with Lethal Strike that wounds with a natural to-wound roll of ‘6’ has its AP always set to 10, and it ignores Fortitude Saves.

rulebook-magical_attacks.title: Magical Attacks
rulebook-magical_attacks.def: The Attack Attribute doesn’t confer any direct effects, but instead interacts with other rules, such as Aegis (X, against Magical Attacks).

rulebook-march_and_shoot.title: March and Shoot
rulebook-march_and_shoot.def: Performing a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/march_move">March Move</nuxt-link> in the same Player Turn does not prevent shooting with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">attacks</nuxt-link> or <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> parts with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/march_and_shoot">March and Shoot</nuxt-link>, but the attack suffers -1 to hit for Moving and Shooting.

rulebook-multiple_wounds.title: Multiple Wounds
rulebook-multiple_wounds.def:
Unsaved wounds caused by the attack are multiplied into the value given in brackets (X). If the value is a dice, roll one dice for each unsaved wound from an attack with Multiple Wounds. The amount of wounds that the attack is multiplied into can never be higher than the Health Points Characteristic of the target, excluding Health Points lost previously in the battle.

For example, if a Multiple Wounds (D6) attack wounds a unit of Trolls (HP 3) and rolls a ‘5’ for the multiplier, the number of unsaved wounds is reduced to 3, even if the Troll unit has already lost one or two Health Points previously in battle.

rulebook-poison_attacks.title: Poison Attacks
rulebook-poison_attacks.def:
If the attack hits with a natural to-hit roll of ‘6’, it automatically wounds (no to-wound roll needed). If the attack has two or more instances of Poison Attacks, it wounds automatically on a successful natural to-hit roll of ‘5’ or ‘6’.

If the attack is turned into more than one hit (e.g. a hit with Area Attack or Fury), only a single hit, chosen by the attacker, automatically wounds. All other hits must roll to wound as normal.

rulebook-quick_to_fire.title: Quick to Fire
rulebook-quick_to_fire.def: The attack doesn't suffer the -1 to-hit modifier for Moving and Shooting.

rulebook-rage.title: Rage
rulebook-rage.def: Whenever the model loses a Health Point, it gains +1 Attack Value. Whenever it Recovers or Raises a Health Point, it suffers -1 Attack Value.

rulebook-shoot_in_extra_rank.title: Shoot in Extra Rank
rulebook-shoot_in_extra_rank.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part may use Shooting <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> from one additional rank. Normally, this means that <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">models</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/shoot_in_extra_rank">Shoot in Extra Rank</nuxt-link> will be able to make Shooting <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> from the third rank.

rulebook-toxic_attacks.title: Toxic Attacks
rulebook-toxic_attacks.def: The attack has its Strength always set to 3 and its Armour Penetration always set to 10.

rulebook-twohanded.title: Two-Handed
rulebook-twohanded.def: A <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> using a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/twohanded">Two-Handed</nuxt-link> Melee Weapon can not simultaneously use a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/shield">Shield</nuxt-link> against <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/melee_attacks">Melee Attacks</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-unwieldy.title: Unwieldy
rulebook-unwieldy.def: If the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> performed a Move Manoeuvre in the same Player Turn, <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attacks">Attacks</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/unwieldy">Unwieldy</nuxt-link> suffer -X to Hit. This modifier can be combined with the -1 to-hit modifier from shooting in the same turn as performing a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/reform_move">Reform Move</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-weapon_master.title: Weapon Master
rulebook-weapon_master.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part may choose what Melee Weapon to use at each Round of Combat, rather than only in the first round of combat. The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part may also choose to use a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/hand_weapon">Hand Weapon</nuxt-link> even if it has another Melee Weapon. If armed with an Enchantment Weapon, the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> part must still use it.

rulebook-zeal.title: Zeal
rulebook-zeal.def: An attack with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/zeal">Zeal</nuxt-link> must reroll failed <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/towound_rolls">to-wound rolls</nuxt-link>.

rulebook-elven_finesse.title: Elven Finesse
rulebook-elven_finesse.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Model</nuxt-link> parts with this Attack Attribute wielding <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/great_weapon">Great Weapons</nuxt-link> strike at -1 Agility instead of always at Agility 0.

rulebook-first_strike.title: First Strike
rulebook-first_strike.def: During the First Round of Combat, model parts with First Strike, or using a weapon with First Strike, gains the rules and Characteristic modifiers stated in brackets. For example, a model part with First Strike (+1 Str) gains +1 Str in the first round of combat.

rulebook-direct_hit.title: Direct Hit
rulebook-direct_hit.def: When the attack hits, after determining the number of hits (e.g. using Area Attack), one single of the hits chosen by the attacker, has its Str and AP multiplied by two, and gains Multiple Wounds (X).

rulebook-horror.title: Horror
rulebook-horror.def:
Such is the dismay inspired by certain beings that enemies can be paralysed with fear, freezing their limbs in place and overwhelming their minds with a primal dread, leaving them at the mercy of their tormentors.
Flee Moves from enemy units made in the following situations are subject to underlinetwo instances of Minimised Roll:


  • Flee! Charge Reactions declared in reaction to a Charge Declaration from a unit containing this rule. (Flee! Charge Reactions declared when later charged by other units are unaffected.)

  • Breaking from combat while in contact with one or more units containing Horror.​



Remember that units containing Fearless are unaffected by this rule.

rulebook-breath_attack.title: Breath Attack
rulebook-breath_attack.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/march_and_shoot">March and Shoot</nuxt-link>. Hits automatically (no to-hit roll required). The Strength, Armour Penetration, and additional <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attack_attributes">Attack Attributes</nuxt-link> are defined in brackets (X).

rulebook-grind_attack.title: Grind Attack
rulebook-grind_attack.def:
The model part can make a Special Melee Attack. Allocate this attack towards a Health Pool in contact with the model, except that it can not be allocated towards an Attachable Model that could not be the target of a Shooting Attack (see Attacks chapter).

The attack is resolved with the model part’s Agility, and hits automatically, inflicting X hits, using the model part’s Strength, Armour Penetration, and Attack Attributes, but not Weapons.

If values for Strength, Armour Penetration and additional Attack Attributes are defined in the bracket (Y), these are used instead. In this case, note that characteristics modifiers and Attack Attributes on the model part itself do not affect this attack.

rulebook-impact_hits.title: Impact Hits
rulebook-impact_hits.def:
If Charging, the model part can make X Special Melee Attack. Allocate this attack towards a Health Pool in contact with the model, except taht it can not be allocated towards an Attachable Model that could not be the target of a Shooting Attack (see Attacks chapter).

T attack is resolved at Agility Step 10, and hits automatically, using the model part’s Strength, Armour Penetration, and Attack Attributes, but not Weapons.

If values for Strength, Armour Penetration and additional Attack Attributes are defined in the bracket (Y), these are used instead. In this case, note that characteristics modifiers and Attack Attributes on the model part itself do not affect this attack.


If more than one model part of a combined model has Impact Hit, only a single Model Part can perform its Impact Hits in each Round of Combat (owner’s choice).

rulebook-stomp_attacks.title: Stomp Attacks
rulebook-stomp_attacks.def:
The model part can make a special Melee Attack. Allocate this attack towards a Health Pool of Height 0 - 1 and in contact with the model, except taht it can not be allocated towards an Attachable Model that could not be the target of a Shooting Attack (see Attacks chapter).

The attack is resolved at Agility Step 0, and hits automatically, inflicting X hits, using the model part’s Strength, Armour Penetration and Attack Attributes, but not Weapons.

If values for Strength, Armour Penetration and additional Attack Attributes are defined in the bracket (Y), these are used instead. In this case, note that characteristics modifiers and Attack Attributes on the model part itself do not affect this attack.


If more than one model part of a combined model has Stomp Attack, only a single Model Part can perform its Stomp Attack in each Round of Combat (owner’s choice).

rulebook-sweeping_attack.title: Sweeping Attack
rulebook-sweeping_attack.def:
When a model with Sweeping Attack is within 1" of an unengaged enemy unit during a Move Manoeuvre (often temporarily), the model’s unit may perform a Sweeping Attack against the enemy unit. This can only be used once per Player Turn. Resolve the Sweeping Attack when the Move Manoeuvre is completed.

The attack hits automatically, and counts as a Ranged Attack. Each model in the unit with Sweeping Attack must use their Sweeping Attack against the same enemy unit. The Sweeping Attack hits automatically, causing a number of hits as defined in the brackets (X hits). These hits are resolved with the model part’s Strength, Armour Penetration and Attack Attributes, but not Weapons.

If values for Strength, Armour Penetration and additional Attack Attributes are defined in the bracket (Y), these are used instead. In this case, note that characteristics modifiers and Attack Attributes on the model part itself do not affect this attack.

rulebook-standard_bearer.title: Standard Bearer
rulebook-standard_bearer.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/standard_bearer">Standard Bearer</nuxt-link> is a unit-wide upgrade, normally represented by the presence of a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> carrying the unit standard, icon, military insignia, totem, or other similar symbol. A unit containing a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/standard_bearer">Standard Bearer</nuxt-link> adds +1 to the Combat Score of its side.

rulebook-musician.title: Musician
rulebook-musician.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/musician">Musician</nuxt-link> is a unit-wide upgrade, normally represented by the presence of a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> as the leader or a regimental <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/musician">musician</nuxt-link>. <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/command_tests">Command Tests</nuxt-link> taken by units containing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/musician">Musician</nuxt-link> are passed on 3+. If a unit contains both <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/musician">Musician</nuxt-link> and <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/unruly">Unruly</nuxt-link>, the rules cancel each other out (which normally means <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/command_tests">Command Tests</nuxt-link> are passed on 4+).

rulebook-duplicate_model_rules.title: Duplicate Model Rules
rulebook-duplicate_model_rules.def: Most <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Model</nuxt-link> Rules are not cumulative. This means that if a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> gains the same rule multiple times, the effects don’t stack or provide extra benefits. If a <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">model</nuxt-link> has multiple instances of the same rule, but with different <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/keywords">keywords</nuxt-link> <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/attached">attached</nuxt-link>, these are considered different <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Model</nuxt-link> Rules, unless otherwise specified.

rulebook-model_rules_and_units.title: Model Rules and Units
rulebook-model_rules_and_units.def:
Even though Model Rules are given to individual models, there are some Model Rules that function on unit level, such as dictating how entire units can move or operate. Model Rules differentiate between the following cases:


  • Units with X: Whenever a Model Rule or Property is referred to as units with the rule, this means units where every single model in it has Rule X or Property X.

  • Units containing X: Whenever a Model Rule is referred to as units containing the rule, this means units where at least one model in it has Rule X or Property X.

  • Units not containing X: Whenever a Model Rule is referred to as units not containing the rule, this means units where no single model in it has Rule X or Property X.

rulebook-attack_attributes.title: Attack Attributes
rulebook-attack_attributes.def:
Attack attributes is a subcategory of Model Rules. While most Model Rules apply to the entire model, including all model parts on the same base, Attack Attributes are the exception, and only affect individual model parts, or even individual attacks.


Attack Attributes for models are therefore written under the Offensive Characteristics part of the model entry, and thus only affect the specific model part it’s listed under. Note however that if an Attack Attribute is given to a unit (e.g. as a result of a spell), it applies to every model part in that unit, and if given to a model, it applies to all parts of that model.
In addition to being given to a model part, Attack Attributes can also be given to a weapon, a spell, or an attack. Such Attack Attributes only affect attacks made with those specific sources. They won’t affect other attacks made by the same model part.
Attack Attributes by default only affect Melee Attacks. There are two main exceptions to this:


  • An Attack Attribute given specifically to a weapon, a spell or attack will affect it regardless of if it would normally only be applicable to Melee Attacks.

  • Attack Attributes that come with their own Strength, Armour Penetration, and Attacks are not affected by Attack Attributes on the model part. For example, a dragon might have Breath Attack (Str, AP, Flaming Attacks) and Lethal Strike. The hits from its Breath Attack are not affected by Lethal Strike, since this is an Attribute on the dragon itself.

rulebook-weapons.title: Weapons
rulebook-weapons.def:
Weapons is a subcategory of Model Rules. Similarly with Attack Attributes, Weapons can only be used by the model part that has the rule. Model parts with Mount, Beast, or Construct cannot use Weapons, unless specifically stated otherwise (e.g. a Beast Model Parts with a Weapons directly on its Profile can use this weapon).

There are three types of weapons:


  • Melee Weapon: A model part can only use a single Melee Weapon, if the model is equipped with multiple Melee Weapons, choose which one to use in the first Round of Combat. This choice is then kept until the model is no longer Engaged in Combat. Melee Weapons are used with the model part’s Standard Melee Attacks.



  • Modifiers to Offensive Characteristics and Attack Attributes are applied only to the model part’s Standard Melee Attacks.

  • Modifiers to Global or Defensive Characteristics (Mob, Cha, Cou, Def, HP, Res, or Arm), and Model Rules that are not Attack Attributes, are applied to the model or model part (see rules for Character Mounts for details when and how Characteristics of mounts are affected) at all times except while using a different Melee Weapon.

  • Variable bonuses, such as those based on a dice roll, are determined at the start of the Agility Step in which the weapon is used.




  • Shooting Weapon: Shooting Weapons are used for making Shooting Attacks. Each model part can only use one Shooting Weapon per phase. A Shooting Weapon typically has an Aim Value, shown in brackets after the name of the weapon. The rules for the Shooting Weapon will define the weapon’s maximum Range, the number of Shots fired, and the Strength, Armour Penetration, and potentially Attack Attributes applied to its attacks.

rulebook-keywords.title: Keywords
rulebook-keywords.def:
Model Rules include keywords to help define their effects. These keywords can be used directly within the rulebook, which applies to rules that always have that keyword. Alternatively, keywords can be specified for individual rules on specific models, spells, or weapons. In this case this is done within brackets following the name of the rule.

Below follows a list of Model Rule keywords:


  • Shooting or Melee & Shooting (Attack Attributes only): An Attack Attribute with the keyword Shooting only affects attacks made with Shooting Weapons, while an Attack Attribute with the keyword Melee & Shooting affects both Melee Attacks and attacks made with Shooting Weapons.


  • Remember that the default if none of these keywords are used is that Attack Attributes only affect Melee Attacks.

  • For example, by default Poison Attacks affect only Melee Attacks. If a model part has Poison Attacks (Shooting), this means the Poison Attacks rule applies only to attacks made with that model part’s Shooting Weapons, unless it also has Poison Attacks or Poison Attacks (Melee & Shooting).



  • Cumulative: Effects from multiple instances of a Model Rule with the Cumulative keyword are combined and add up.

  • Distance Modifiers: Denoted as a number followed by ". Any distances in the Model Rule description is replaced by the number. For example, Vanguard (3"") means that the model can perform a Vanguard move, but its Mobility is set to 3" instead of the normal 6".

  • Towards X: The Attack Attribute only applies if the attack is allocated to a specific type of enemy model. The conditions are given as X. If more than one type of enemy is relevant they are separated by or. If multiple conditions must be fulfilled, these conditions are separated by and. For example, Multiple Wounds (2, towards Height 4 and Beast, or Height 5) means that Multiple Wounds can be used versus models that are both Height 4 and Beast, as well as versus models that are Height 5, regardless of if the model has the Beast Property or not.

  • Against X: The Model Rule only applies when attacked by a certain type of model or with certain Rules or Properties. See the rules under Towards X for how to interpret or and and. For example, Hard Target (against Lethal Strike) means that the model can only use its Hard Target rule when attacked by an attack with Lethal Strike.

  • Unique Keywords: In addition to the standard model rule keywords defined above, certain Model Rules have unique keywords. These are defined in the respective rules themselves.

rulebook-introduction.def:
Welcome to the tabletop wargame known as The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, or T9A for short. This is a community crafted miniatures wargame, where grand armies collide in monumental conflicts for supremacy and survival. The game is played on a tabletop with terrain features and miniatures to represent the battlefield and the clashing armies, and it uses six-sided dice and measuring devices to move miniatures and resolve actions such as charging into battle, letting arrows loose, and casting spells.

For all the rules, feedback, and suggestions, please visit our webpage: the-ninth-age.com. The rules presented in this book are considered the Core Rules of T9A and are used in all T9A games. : Copyright Creative Commons

/section{rules_representation}/section{rules_documents}
rulebook-introduction.title: Introduction

rulebook-rules_representation.def:
In order to keep rules clear and tidy, the following text formatting is used:

Text in a grey box denotes designer notes. In these are the designers giving some insights into intent behind rules, alternate ways to play the game, or shortcuts to speed things up.

  • Capitalization is used for keywords, such as Round of Combat, unless they are common words like model or unit.

  • Bold font or underlined text is used to highlight specific words. It is also used in Army Books to emphasise Model Rules specified in the same unit entry.

  • Italic font marks reminders, examples, clarifications, and other content that is not direct rules.

  • Grey-coloured text is used for figure and table captions, item restrictions, repetitive content, and Properties, which is a special type of keyword that doesn’t transfer any direct rules.

  • Hyperlinks can be found in the electronic version of this document, and the page footer includes hyperlinks to key sections.

  • Pink text is unique to Appendix IV - Reference Manual. This appendix covers corner-cases and specific circumstances that are not expected to be relevant in the majority of games. The appendix is a copy of the core Rulebook with a few additional sections added to cover these corner-cases.

The Sunna Myth

Part one

In the age when the sun's warmth waned and daylight grew fleeting, our land fell under the shadow of encroaching darkness. Beasts of the wild, marauders of the wastes, and titans of the mountains descended upon us, sweeping all in their path. From this chaos emerged Bragh, the Black Bull, a harbinger of destruction who laid waste to our lands with his mighty mace. Our people, the Askar, faced annihilation as Bragh's rampage pressed relentlessly westward.
In our hour of despair, King Warin, our valiant ruler, rallied ninety brave warriors to hold a vital ford over the Gewache River, buying precious time for our people to flee. As twilight fell, Warin sought solace and strength at a riverside shrine, beseeching the gods for aid.
Amidst the darkness, our defenders fought fiercely, their blades stained with the blood of foes. Yet, Bragh's relentless advance threatened to overwhelm us. With a single, devastating blow, he shattered the King's shield and arm, poised to deliver the final stroke. But then, a lone figure emerged from the fray, a warrior with golden hair flowing and determination in her eyes. In a blaze of radiant light, she confronted Bragh the Black Bull, her sword ablaze with divine fire. With three swift strikes she brought the monstrous Bull to his knees, ending his reign of terror.
As Bragh fell, the beasts fled, and our people emerged from the chaos to witness the dawn of a new era. King Warin, kneeling before his saviour, recognized her as Sunna, the goddess of light, whose arrival had answered his fervent prayers.
rulebook-rules_representation.title: Rules representation

rulebook-rules_documents.def:
This document is the Appendix IV: Reference Manual, which includes all rules from the core rulebook, the Appendix I: Model Rules and the Appendix II: Arcane Compendium documents. Additionally, it includes extended rules text to cover for intricate and complex battlefield situations.
This document is the core rulebook, containing the main rules needed for playing the game. In addition to this, you will need a few more documents to play a full game of T9A.\fi

Core Rulebook

The core rulebook contains the main rules needed for playing the game.
Appendices

Appendices are an integral component of the core rules, and are generally used in most games. There are four appendices:

  • Appendix I: Model Rules -- Additional and unique rules that specific models possess.

  • Appendix II: Arcane Compendium -- The compendium contains spells from the ten different paths of magic, along with the common Magic Items.

  • Appendix III: Season Packs -- Comprising deployment types, maps, and secondary objectives, this appendix caters to more advanced games.

  • Appendix IV: Reference Manual -- This manual thoroughly covers rules for intricate and complex battlefield situations.

  • For new players and those who prefer to deal with intricate scenarios as they arise, we suggest starting with the Core Rulebook and only referring to the Reference Manual when specific situations occur that are not fully covered in the Core Rulebook.

  • We recommend that players who prefer to understand complex situations in advance and fully grasp the nuances of all rule interactions turn directly to this document.

Army Books

The rules for the different armies are found in Army Books. Within these, you will find army composition rules, unit and model rules, characteristics, and so on.

Supplements

Supplements are optional add-ons to the game that require an agreement with the opponent before using.
rulebook-rules_documents.title: Rules Documents

rulebook-the_flow_of_the_game.def:
This game is divided into three main sections, performed in order.

1 - Battle Preparations. Before a game, certain preparations are needed. The players need to put together their armies, prepare the Battlefield, select victory conditions and deploy their armies onto the Battlefield.

2 - Game Turns. This is a turn-based game, with standard games comprising six Game Turns. Each Game Turn is further divided into two Player Turns, wherein each player takes turns controlling their respective armies in a series of phases which are performed in the following sequence:

  • Charge Phase

  • Movement Phase

  • Magic Phase

  • Shooting Phase

  • Rally Phase

  • Melee Phase

3 - After the Game. After both players have played six Player Turns, it’s time to tally up the Victory Points and check who managed to win the Primary and Secondary Objectives to see who is the winner of the Game.

Greeeetings! I am Klepa, one hundred percent honest and reliable merchant goblin. This is my healthful and fine-smelling accomplice – ah – pet! my charming pet: Fleabag. For smallest of prices, and promise not to talk to mean old city guards, we can be your guides here. Klepa will share all his, er, lawfully ack-quee-zis-shined knowledge about the wide world of the Ninth Age! Such a pleasure to meet a new mark – I mean customer! Customer and friend! Welcome

Active & Reactive Player


The Active Player is the one currently taking their Player Turn, and the Reactive Player is the one whose Player Turn is not currently happening.

Your First Game


Is this your first game? Let’s get you started. First, prepare your battlefield: a large flat surface with model terrain on – a pile of books can be a hill, a mug can be a rock, a mouse pad can be a lake, and so on. Then, challenge a friend to a game where you both command your own miniature army.

For a trial run without the commitment of time and resources, we offer downloadable paper cutouts on the T9A website (address provided at the beginning of this book).

If you’re uncertain about which army to choose, a brief overview of the 16 main armies and their primary themes can be found in the Introduction chapter.
rulebook-the_flow_of_the_game.title: The Flow of the Game

rulebook-battle_preparations.def:
Before battle can be joined, you must establish the nature of the battlefield, the armies that will fight upon it, and their reason for being there. This is a natural part of setting up the game, but it can also represent a commander reviewing their troops and scouting the land in preparation for an important battle.

When preparing to play a game of The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles, players follow a series of steps known as the Battle Preparations.

1 - Pregame planning (typically done before players arrive to the gaming table)

  • Army Size is decided, which determines the size of the game. This can be done by the players agreeing on an Army Size, or an outside source such as campaign rules or a tournament organiser dictating this.

  • Build an Army. Each player creates an Army Lists from one of the Armybooks.

2 - Initial preparations (these are sometimes done before arrival - typical in a tournament setting, and sometimes done by both players together - typical in more casual settings)

  • Build the Battlefield by setting up terrain and scenery to create an engaging and challenging environment for the battle.

  • Share Army Lists with your opponent, revealing the units and options you will be using during the game.

  • Select Victory Conditions. Normally this means picking Primary and Secondary Objectives, which define the goals for the coming battle.

  • Select Deployment Type, which defines how the armies will be placed on the Battlefield before the game begins.

3 - Battle setup (these actions are done at the gaming table by both players together)

  • Decide Deployment Zones, which are the areas where each player's units will be positioned during deployment.

  • Pregame Selections. Choices to make before deployment are made at this step. The most common choice is wizards with the option to replace spells.

  • Deploy units. Players place their units within their designated deployment zones.

  • Move Vanguarding units. Units with the model rule Vanguard perform their pre-game movement.

  • Roll for the first turn. The battle can begin!

Appendix III: Season Packs, is an annually updated supplement that can provide support in building a battlefield and adds several variations on deployment types, Primary Objectives and Secondary Objectives. If you are looking for a fast and simple game, or this is one of your first games, we recommend you use the rules below and leave Appendix III for next time.

Planning, strategy, knowing terrain, learning about the ponent – very useful for a heist! What? You were asking about battles? Oh yes, Klepa knows them too. We goblins are Warborn after all – that’s the name us and orc pals call ourselves together. Klepa has seen all the great battles, seen loads of action! Normally from quite far away – so you know I had a good view.
Main thing I’ve learned is you’ve got to get there early if you want the best spot for hiding and picking over the loot at the end. You want some loot? Genuine, authentikarated battle gear, picked from the choiciest corpses! Just step quietly over to Appendicitis Numero Two and we’ll have a little chat about the low low prices.

/section{pregame_planning}/section{initial_preparations}/section{battle_setup}
rulebook-battle_preparations.title: Battle Preparations

rulebook-army_size.def:
Before building an army, players need to agree on the size of the battle, which is referred to as Army Size. The combined point costs of all the units in the army should not exceed the designated Army Size, and it is allowed to be not more than max 50 points below the limit.

The rules for army composition are modified depending on the size of an army.

Point Cost


Point Cost, often shortened pts, is a measure of the power of a unit or upgrade. We use pts to ensure that two armies with a similar total Points Cost facing each other is a fair balanced game.

All units have an associated Points Cost, which is determined by adding its starting Point Cost of additional models added to the unit, and Points Cost of the additional options the unit selects.
rulebook-army_size.title: Army Size

rulebook-build_an_army.def:
As the player, it is your duty to command your army on the battlefield, but first you will have to pick one of the different factions available to you. Each Army Book contains a description of the different units that are available to its faction, as well as their characteristics and special rules that apply to them.

To start building your army, you create an Army List, which includes the selection of units, spells and options you want to use along with their point costs. Every unit, weapon, upgrade, and Magic Item has a specific point cost, which is used to balance the game and ensure fair play between players.

/subsubsection{army_books}/subsubsection{unit_entries}/subsubsection{units_belonging_to_more_than_one_army_category}/subsubsection{adding_army_categories_to_a_unit}/subsubsection{splitting_point_cost_between_army_categories}/subsubsection{unit_and_item_restriction}/subsubsection{spell_selection}
rulebook-build_an_army.title: Build an Army

rulebook-army_books.def: The rules for playing the various factions are detailed in Army Books and supplement Army Books (remember that using a supplement requires the agreement of your opponent or event organiser).
rulebook-army_books.title: Army Books

rulebook-unit_entries.def:
Each entry in an Army Book is categorised into different Army Categories, each represented by specific icons in the unit entries of the Army Book. Each Army Category has its own points limit, as defined in the Army Book, determining how many points a player can allocate to that particular category. This allows players to create a balanced and strategic army composition for their games.

characterCharactersThis category typically allows players to spend up to 40% of the Army Size on Characters. All entries that belong to this Army Category follow the rules for Characters and Attachable Models.

Characters are the leaders and exceptional individuals in the army, wielding various skills such as brute force, tactical acumen, spellcasting ability, or engineering knowledge. They play a crucial role in influencing the outcome of battles, and one of them must serve as the army's General, responsible for leading and inspiring your forces.

coreCoreThis Army Category always has a minimum amount of points that must be spent on it, usually 25% of the Army Size.

Core units represent the most readily available warriors in the faction, serving as essential rank-and-file troops under the command of the Characters. They are always present in some combination as part of your fighting force.

specialSpecialThis Army Category has no maximum or minimum limit. You are free to spend any amount of points on units in this Army Category, so long as the requirements of the army composition are met.0.36

The Special Army Category represents less common and more unique forces that are found in some but not all of your faction’s armies. While they might make up the largest portion of your host, , the availability of each unit is still limited. They can often fill a range of useful and impactful roles.

EoSArmy-SpecificThis Army Category has a maximum amount of points that can be spent on it; the limit is defined within individual Army Books.0.30

Army-Specific Categories introduce additional options and limitations in army building, reflecting the nature of the faction. Army-Specific Categories can include thematic groupings of units, limitations based on specific functions, and sometimes the faction’s most rare and powerful forces.
rulebook-unit_entries.title: Unit Entries

rulebook-units_belonging_to_more_than_on.def: Some units can be included in more than one Army Category, which is represented by more than one icon in their entry. In these cases, simply count the unit’s Point Cost towards the limits of all its Army Categories, but only once towards the army’s Point Cost.
rulebook-units_belonging_to_more_than_on.title: Units belonging to more than one Army Category

rulebook-adding_army_categories_to_a_uni.def: Choosing certain options can make a unit count towards another Army Category in addition to its original Army Category. For example, giving a unit <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/shooting_weapons">Shooting Weapons</nuxt-link> might make it also count towards the Ranged Support Army Category. This is marked by a small icon of the additional Army Category, displayed underneath the original Army Category icon(s), together with the conditions for counting towards this additional Army Category.
rulebook-adding_army_categories_to_a_uni.title: Adding Army Categories to a Unit

rulebook-splitting_point_cost_between_ar.def:
In some rare cases, a unit’s Point Cost can be split between different Army Categories, where the Point Cost for some particular option is additionally counted towards a different Army Category than the unit. This is marked in the unit entry by a split icon, with the two halves representing the two Army Categories the unit counts towards.

For example, a 250 pts Elf Character, counted towards the Characters Army Category, decides to ride a 500 pts Dragon, which is an option marked to count additionally towards Beasts and Monsters. In this case, the player must count the entire unit’s Point Cost (250 + 500 = 750 pts) towards Characters, and the Dragon’s Point Cost (500 pts) towards “Beasts and Monsters”. Here too, of course, only 750 pts are added towards the army’s total limit.
rulebook-splitting_point_cost_between_ar.title: Splitting Point Cost between Army Categories

rulebook-unit_and_item_restriction.def:
Certain units and options in the army have limitations on how many times they can be included.

  • Maximum unit cost: Unless mentioned otherwise, no unit can have a points cost above 600 points. A unit entry with a different maximum points cost different than this, follows its own defined limits instead. For example, a unit with (max. 800 pts) listed next to its unit size limits can cost up to 800 points.

  • Max. X Items per Army: Some items have an amount of Max. X allowed per army. For example, it might be Max. 2 Units, Max. 2 Models, or Max. 2 Mounts per Army. This means you can choose to include a maximum of X instances of these items in your army.

  • Max. X Combined Items per Army: Some combinations of items may be restricted in combination. In these cases this will be detailed in the Army Organisation part of the Army Book.

  • Max. X Items per Unit: Some items have a maximum limitation allowed per unit. This means you can choose to include up to X instances of these items for each unit.

  • One of a Kind: Items marked as One of a Kind can only be taken once per army.

  • This rule is not affected by Warbands or Grand Armies and remains the same regardless of the army’s points limit.

Restrictions for Army Size

Depending on the Army Size, restrictions may change:

  • Warband (below 3500 points): All Max. X Items per Army restrictions are halved, rounding fractions up.

  • Field Army (3500-6999 points): No additional rules.

  • Grand Army (7000 points and above): All Max. X Items per Army restrictions are doubled.

  • Exception: One of a Kind is not doubled for Grand Armies.

1.20damselLudaman.png
rulebook-unit_and_item_restriction.title: Unit and item Restriction

rulebook-spell_selection.def:
Models that can cast spells are called Wizards. Each Wizard must choose a Path of Magic to select spells from. Which Paths are available is specified under each Wizard unit entry. This choice of Path of Magic and spells are written on the Army List.

Different types of Wizards know a different number of spells, and can choose spells of different types.

  • Wizard Apprentice: 1 spell from Apprentice Spells (#1).

  • Wizard Adept: 3 spells from Apprentice Spell and Adept Spells (#1 - #4).

  • Wizard Master: 4 spells from Apprentice Spell, Adept Spells, and Master Spells (#1 - #6).

  • Wizard Conclaves (X): X spells from the list of spells specified under each unit with Wizard Conclave.

  • Protean Magic (X): X spells. The Wizard doesn't choose a Path of Magic. Instead, it knows all the Apprentice Spells (#1) of all Paths of Magic it has access to.

During Pre-game Selections, Wizards may replace their selection or swap spells for the Hereditary spell in its Army Book. See 3.2 Pregame Selections for details.

To save time and space on Army List writing, we recommend that the wizard level of a model is followed by the path name with the numbers of the selected spells in brackets.
For example, Wizard Adept, Alchemy (2, 3, 4).
rulebook-spell_selection.title: Spell Selection

rulebook-share_army_lists.def:
After deciding on the size of the game, the next step for both players is to share Army Lists and all relevant information about the upcoming game.

Sharing Army Lists before the game starts allows both players to look up the rules that apply to the units to be involved in the game, so that they understand how those will function and can plan their strategy accordingly, avoiding any unpleasant surprises, and minimising the time spent on time reading rules in the Army Books while playing.
rulebook-share_army_lists.title: Share Army Lists

rulebook-build_the_battlefield.def:
While the game is playable on a wide variety of sizes of the Battlefield, we recommend that the following sizes are adhered to. This provides a good balance between enough room to manoeuvre your troops, without having so much room that there is hardly any engagement.

  • Battlefield Size: The game is played on a rectangular Battlefield, with two main measurements:

  • Short Table Edge: The main direction along which the two opposing armies face each other. We recommend 48" regardless of Army Size.

  • Long Table Edge: In most Deployment Types the long table edge is the direction along which the units of each army is lined up. The bigger the armies are, the longer the table edge you need to fit all the units. See the table beside for recommandations.

  • Terrain placement: The Terrain on the Battlefield is essential for adding depth and strategic elements to the game. It can represent various features, from simple objects to more significant landmarks. Players have the flexibility to determine the size, type, and number of Terrain Features, as well as their placements. There are prebuilt maps available in Appendix III: Season Packs.
rulebook-build_the_battlefield.title: Build the Battlefield

rulebook-select_victory_conditions.def:
The Victory Conditions for the games is divided into three parts (see chapter Winning the Game for their relative importance);

  • Victory Points, meaning how much of the opponent’s army has been destroyed.

  • A single Primary Objective that both players compete to win, and

  • If using Secondary Objective, one for each player. See Appendix III: Rules of Engagement for Secondary Objectives. If this is your first game, we recommend playing without Secondary Objectives.

If no outside source tells you which one to use (e.g. tournament organiser, campaign rule, Appendix III: Rules of Engagement, etc.), players use the Primary Objectives below.

It’s not about winning, they say. Who is Klepa to disagreedy? Just a nice friendly battle with mounds of fallen comraddies – most important thing is to have fun with it! And whatever you do, don’t let the things you’ve seen haunt you the rest of your days!
Scoring Units

Units containing Rank-and-File models that fulfil all conditions below are considered a Scoring Unit:

  • It has a Standard Bearer.

  • It does not have Light Troops.

  • It was not Summoned during the game.

Rank-and-File units

Any unit containing Rank-and-File models is considered a Rank-and-File unit.

Destroyed in Combat

The following scenarios are all considered cases of a unit being Destroyed in Combat:

  • A unit loses its last Health Point whilst Engaged in Combat (including as a result of losing Health Point from Combat Score, e.g. from Supernal and Unstable).

  • A unit Breaks from combat and is caught by a pursuing unit.

  • A unit Breaks from combat and is removed as Casualty during its Flee Move (e.g. due to Dangerous Terrain Tests, Shaken off the table, etc.).

For this, consider the original unit, meaning as listed on the Army List. This means that the Rank-and-File part of a unit might be Destroyed in Combat, while an Attachable Model joined to the unit is not, or vice versa.

1214.4Primary Objective - Spoils of War

When an enemy unit is Destroyed in Combat, the opposing player puts one Spoils Token on one of their Scoring Units (if there are any) that was just engaged with the unit Destroyed in Combat.

A unit loses all of its Spoils Tokens when any of the following occurs:

  • The last Health Point on its Rank-and-File models (see Models and Units in the Definitions and Terminology chapter) is lost .

  • It becomes Shaken. Remember that units that perform a Flee Move automatically become Shaken.

At the end of the game, the player with the most Spoils Token on their units wins this Primary Objective.
rulebook-select_victory_conditions.title: Select Victory Conditions

rulebook-select_deployment_type.def:
If no outside source tells you what Deployment Type to use, players can use the Frontline Clash standard deployment type instead, or choose one from Appendix III : Season Pack.

Frontline Clash
