rulebook-opaque_terrain.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/line_of_sight">Line of Sight</nuxt-link> cannot be drawn through <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/opaque_terrain">Opaque Terrain</nuxt-link>, but can be drawn into or out of it. <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/model">Models</nuxt-link> always ignore <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/opaque_terrain">Opaque Terrain</nuxt-link> they are inside for drawing <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/line_of_sight">Line of Sight</nuxt-link>.
rulebook-opaque_terrain.title: Opaque Terrain

rulebook-covering_terrain.def:
Covering Terrain contributes to Cover when drawing Line of Sight through it. The bracket (X) indicates if the terrain contributes to Soft Cover or Hard Cover.

Certain Terrain Features (such as Ruins and Fields) only count as Covering Terrain for units in contact with them. Ignore any Terrain Feature the shooter itself is located in for Cover purposes.

Covering Terrain always has a bracket (Height Y) associated with it that corresponds to the largest Height where this Terrain Feature can contribute to Cover. For example, Fields are Covering Terrain (Height 3), this means that anything with a Height of 4 or above cannot claim Soft Cover from Line of Sight drawn through a Field they are in contact with.
rulebook-covering_terrain.title: Covering Terrain

rulebook-disruptive.def: Units in <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/contact">contact</nuxt-link> with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/disruptive">Disruptive</nuxt-link> cannot claim Combat Score bonus from their Proper Ranks.
rulebook-disruptive.title: Disruptive

rulebook-terrain_types.def:
A Terrain Feature is a topographical area on the Battlefield that may be a mixture of Dangerous, Opaque, or Covering Terrain and may possess its own set of rules. Most Terrain Features belong to one of the Terrain Types given below, and follow the corresponding rules:

/subsection{fields}/subsection{forests}/subsection{hills}/subsection{impassable_terrain}/subsection{ruins}/subsection{walls}/subsection{water_terrain}
rulebook-terrain_types.title: Terrain Types

rulebook-fields.def:
Fields can be represented in the game for example by meadows of tall grass or agricultural enclosures.

Fields have the following rules:

  • Covering Terrain (Soft Cover, Height 3) for units in contact with the Field.

  • Flammable: Units in contact with a Field gain Weakness (Flaming Attacks).
rulebook-fields.title: Fields

rulebook-forests.def:
Forests can be represented for example by jungles, brushwoods, or small groves of trees.

Forests have the following rules:

  • Dangerous Terrain (6+, Mounted).

  • Covering Terrain (Soft Cover, Height 5).

  • Disruptive.
rulebook-forests.title: Forests

rulebook-hills.def:
Hills can be represented for example by elevated plateaus or burial mounds.

Hills have the following rules:

  • Opaque Terrain. Remember that Line of Sight can still be drawn into and out of the Terrain Feature.

  • Elevated Position: A model is considered to have an Elevated Position if it is fully on a Hill. When drawing Line of Sight to or from a model with Elevated Position, ignore intervening models that do not have an Elevated Position.
rulebook-hills.title: Hills

rulebook-impassable_terrain.def:
Impassable Terrain can be represented for example by monoliths, cliffs, massive boulders, or buildings.

Impassable Terrain has the following rules:

  • Opaque Terrain.

  • Dangerous Terrain (4+) for units making Flee Moves through Impassable Terrain.

  • Solid: Models cannot move into or through Impassable Terrain (except as part of a Flee Move).
rulebook-impassable_terrain.title: Impassable Terrain

rulebook-ruins.def:
Ruins can be represented for example by rubble, abandoned farmsteads or ancient sites of symbolic or arcane power.

Ruins have the following rules:

  • Covering Terrain (Hard Cover, Height 3) for units in contact with the Ruin.

  • Dangerous Terrain (6+).
rulebook-ruins.title: Ruins

rulebook-walls.def:
Walls can be represented for example by stone, wood, or makeshift structures.

Walls have the following rules:

  • Covering Terrain (Hard Cover, Height 3) for units in contact with the Wall.

  • Fortified Position: Melee Attacks from Charging models that are in contact with a Wall suffer -1 to hit. This also applies to Supporting Attacks made by charging models over models in contact with a Wall, and Attacks across gaps where the model’s virtual extended base would be in contact with a wall.
rulebook-walls.title: Walls

rulebook-water_terrain.def:
Water Terrain can be represented in the game for example by ponds, swamps, or rivers.

Water Terrain has the following rules:

  • Dangerous Terrain (6+, Metal Armour).

  • Disruptive.

  • Conductive: Units in contact with Water Terrain gain Weakness (Lightning Attacks).

  • Unsure Footing: Stomp Attacks and Impact Hits cannot be used by models that are in contact with Water Terrain.
rulebook-water_terrain.title: Water Terrain

rulebook-the_world_of_the_9th_age.def:
The Ninth Age is a time of epic clashes and feats of arms, of legends, myths, monsters and magic. After nine long ages of strife, the many peoples and kingdoms of this high fantasy world have acquired highly developed and often spectacular methods of waging war. With so many great and terrible powers throughout the lands, the future is poised and uncertain: Everything could be decided on the outcome of a single battle.

For the reader who wishes to delve deeper into the lore of the Ninth Age, you can discover more of the wider setting in each Army Book, as well as our background-focused publications: the-ninth-age.com/the-world.

Among the various cultures, countries, and strange dominions of the world, sixteen great factions are pre-eminent. Each of these powers represents a terrifying military force. Each will attempt to dominate the Ninth Age as they are able, and each has connections that can bring it across the globe. As such, there is never any shortage of reasons for conflict and battle between these mighty armies - as your tabletop games can testify.

1214.4Few individuals have the chance to see more than a fraction of our world, with its astonishing variety of intelligent races and animal species, plants and cities, cults and wars. I have travelled from Avras to the Kingdom of Vanhu. I’ve seen Sunna’s seeds planted in Virentia and the Great Wall of Tsuandan in the far east of Augea. You could not find another who has travelled a greater distance; I have been protected by the auspice of Sunna, and here I record my knowledge on the geography of our world.
Vetia is the land of mankind, where nations of men have reigned for years under the protective sight of the Goddess and her church. There, the powerful nation of Sonnstahl guards all mankind against the dangers of the Wasteland, while to the south the merchant cities of Arcalea ply their trade with the whole of the world. There you will also find the White Mountains, impenetrable hold of the Dwarves. To the west lie the twin cities of Destria, the Kingdom of noble Equitaine, and the enchanted, emerald-green forest of Wyscan, the mysterious dwelling of the sylvan elves.Augea, the immense sister of Vetia, separated from one another by the great Wasteland, home to the servants of the Dark Gods. Crossing east of Avras into this land, you will travel through the Barren Mountains, where the Steel Road starts its winding journey. Here is the dwelling of the Dwarves of the east, named Infernal. The Steel Road runs parallel to the Silk Road to the north, with access controlled by the Ogre Khans. It leads from the Blasted Plains through the Sky Mountains, across the northern part of the human region of Sagarikadesha, finishing its rich path in the glorious land of Tsuandan, where the Dragon Emperor rules over men.
Set sail south from Bellatorre, and in three nights you will reach the docks of Port Reynaud, Equitaine’s holdfast in Taphria. Should you dare it, you will never forget the nights spent in the Great Desert, for they are terrible and fascinating all at once. There, following the path of the Napaat river, lie the remains of a truly ancient kingdom with its legends of never-dying monstrosities. In the west stand the fortresses and souks of Qassar, full of exotic smells and tales of evil spirits, the djinn. In the west and southeast of the continent lie vast kingdoms of men; the Koghi Empire and Kingdom of Vanhu respectively. Finally in its south, the forests around the Mfumu river are said to hide some of the most ancient secrets of the world.
The Great Ocean divides Vetia from the two western continents, Silexia in the north and Virentia in the south. The Ocean itself is the dominion of elves: there the fleets of the two great nations, the Highborn and their dreaded kin, vie for supremacy. Here lies the main motherland of the Highborn Elves, the proud islands of Celeda Ablan, and Silexia where freedom is a commodity to be traded.
On the eastern coast of Virentia mankind too, has established colonies: the imperial city of Fredericksberg, and the port of Aguadulce, of Destria. Beyond them, a lush forest of wonderful colors and inconceivable dan- gers hides the secrets of ancient civilizations. Dividing Virentia from Silexia, the Shattered Sea; a rumoured maelstrom of magic and tempests, from which no vessel returns.
A New Atlas for the Ninth Age, by Johannes Strabo
rulebook-the_world_of_the_9th_age.title: The World of the 9th Age

rulebook-psychology.def:
Every commander must face the reality that their troops might not always obey their orders. Soldiers who lack proper military training and discipline may not be able to execute more complex field operations satisfactorily. And when you ask even the hardiest warrior to face monstrous terrors, or stand firm when their comrades perish and flee, you should be prepared for the eventuality that their resolve may falter.

In The Ninth Age: Fantasy Battles, there are two types of Psychology Tests that represent a warrior’s mental state and ability to follow orders: Command and Courage.

/section{command_tests}/section{courage_tests}/section{psychology_states}
rulebook-psychology.title: Psychology

rulebook-command_tests.def:
To perform a Command test, roll a D6. If the result is 4+, the test is passed. Otherwise, it fails. Certain rules, abilities and situations may modify this roll. The most common ones are due to Model Rules such as Disciplined, Mindless, Musician, and Unruly, see Appendix I: Model Rules for full details.

The most common situations where Command Tests are taken are:

  • When attempting to Redirect a Charge. Remember this can only be attempted once per phase.

  • When attempting to Restrain from Pursuing a Broken enemy, and

  • When attempting to perform a Combat Reform
when on the losing side of a combat.

Panic? Klepa is always cool as coocumber. What’s the secret to staying calm? Just remember: you are an honest goblin with a pure heart, nothing to hide, and lots of eemaculit alibis.
rulebook-command_tests.title: Command Tests

rulebook-courage_tests.def:
To perform a Courage test, roll 2D6 and compare the result with the highest Courage value in the unit (see Characteristic Profiles in the Definitions and Terminology chapter). If the result is equal to or lower than the Courage value, the test is passed. Otherwise, it fails.

There are three primary types of Courage Tests;

  • Panic Tests: Tests of Panic are taken immediately whenever a unit is called upon to take a Panic Tests, see below for the most common situations. A failed Panic Test puts a unit in a Shaken state.

  • Rally Tests: Taken during the
Rally Phase (after the Shooting
Phase) by all the Active Player’s
Shaken units. See Rally Phase
chapter for details.

  • Break Tests: Taken by units on the
losing side of a Combat, see Melee
Phase for details.

at (current page.south east)
-1
;

/subsection{panic_tests}
rulebook-courage_tests.title: Courage tests

rulebook-panic_tests.def:
A Panic test is a type of Courage Test taken in certain situations. These situations include:

  • A friendly Shaken unit performs a Flee Move through the unit.

  • A Flee Move that is the direct consequence of a voluntary decision does not cause a Panic Test to friendly units.
This includes Charge Reaction Flee! (unless caused by a failed Panic Test when charged by a model with Terror), and voluntary Breaking from Combat with a unit with Feigned Flight. Note that a Flee Move due to a failed Rally Test is not considered a voluntary Flee Move, even if originally due to a Charge Reaction Flee!.

  • Take the test after completing the Flee Move.

  • The unit suffered Health Point losses equal to or greater than 25% of the number of Health Points that it had at the start of the phase, from Ranged Attacks originating from enemy models. Take the Panic Test immediately after possible casualties have been removed.

  • An enemy unit with Terror declares a charge against the unit.

  • Ignore Health Point losses suffered while Engaged in Combat.

Units do not take Panic Tests if

  • they are Engaged in Combat, or

  • they are already Shaken, or

  • they already passed a Panic Test during this phase.

If a unit fails a Panic test, it immediately becomes Shaken. Note that this normally does not mean the unit performs a Flee Move.
rulebook-panic_tests.title: Panic Tests

rulebook-psychology_states.def:
Units may suffer from various psychological states, which can limit their actions. It is recommended to use markers to indicate the current state of each unit.

Note that units can be in multiple states simultaneously.

/subsection{decimated}/subsection{shaken}/subsection{flee_move}
rulebook-psychology_states.title: Psychology States

rulebook-decimated.def:
A model is considered Decimated when its original* unit’s current Health Points is 25% or less of its starting Health Points, as listed in the Army List.

Decimated Models are removed as Casualties just before they would perform a Flee Move.

*Original unit means the units as listed on the Army List. This means that the Rank-and-File part of a unit might be considered Decimated, while an Attachable Model joined to the unit is not, or vice versa. In this case, remove only Decimated models from the unit when performing the Flee Move, and leave models that are not Decimated on the Battlefield.
rulebook-decimated.title: Decimated

rulebook-shaken.def:
When a unit fails a Panic Test or a Break Test or choses Charge Reaction Flee!, it becomes Shaken.

A Shaken unit is unable to perform voluntary actions. This includes declaring Charges, moving in any way other than a Flee Move, Shoot, Generate Magic Dice, cast spells, or activate Magic Items that require voluntary activation. However, there is an exception: the unit may still choose to Flee! or Hold! As a Charge Reaction.

Shaken units that are Engaged in Combat are removed as casualties at step 2.1 of their Round of Combat sequence.

In order to remember which units are Shaken, we recommend that Shaken units are clearly marked. This can either be done with specific markers or tokens to indicate a unit is Shaken, or if you do not have such markers, a commonly used method for marking Shaken units is to put one model from the Front Rank of the Shaken unit, and lie face down next to the unit.
rulebook-shaken.title: Shaken

rulebook-flee_move.def:
A Flee Move is a specific type of move performed in certain situations. The most common instances are failing a Rally Test, choosing to Flee! as a charge reaction or failing a Break Test without being caught by any enemies. When making a Flee Move, follow these steps:
1 - Roll Flee Distance. Normally 2D6.
2 - Each Flee Move starts by Pivoting the unit to face a certain direction.

  • Failed Rally Test: Pivot the unit to face directly away from the closest enemy unit.

The direction is specified by a line from Centre of Unit to Centre of Unit. If there are multiple enemy units at equal distances, the opponent chooses which one of its units will be used for direction of flight.

  • Charge Reaction Flee! and failed Terror Tests: Pivot the unit to face directly away from the Charging enemy.

The direction is specified by a line from Centre of Unit to Centre of Unit.

  • Failed Break Test: Pivot the Shaken unit so that its Rear Facing is parallel with the Facing it was Engaged in of the enemy.

If multiple units are eligible, the opponent chooses which of its units is chosen for this.

3 - Move the Shaken unit straight forward by the distance rolled.
4 - A Flee Move, including the initial Pivot, ignores the Unit Spacing rule, and can move through any obstructions. However, the move cannot end overlapping other units or Impassable Terrain, continue the move in a straight line until the unit can be placed on the battlefield without overlapping obstructions. Remember that the unit ignores the Unit Spacing rule, which means it can be placed within 1" of other units or Impassable Terrain.

  • If the obstacle encountered was a friendly unit, this unit must take a Panic Test.

  • If the obstacle encountered was an enemy unit or Impassable Terrain, treat these as Dangerous Terrain (4+).

5 - If the Flee Move takes the unit into contact with the Table Edge, the unit is removed as a Casualty.
rulebook-flee_move.title: Flee Move

special-properties_of_magic_items.title: Properties of Magic Items
special-properties_of_magic_items.def:
The following terms are common keywords used to describe Magic Items:

  • Magic Items Category: Each Magic Item belongs to a single Magic Item Category, listed below. No model or unit can select more than one Magic Item from each category.

  • Dominant: A model can only have one Dominant Magic Item, no matter it's category.

  • One of a Kind: All Magic Items are One of a Kind, unless stated otherwise.

special-who_is_affected_.title: Who is affected ?
special-who_is_affected_.def:
Unless specifically mentioned otherwise:

  • Global and Defensive Characteristic modifiers are applied only to the model part taking the Magic Item (and not to other model parts such as mounts)*.

  • Model Rules that are not Attack Attributes are applied to the combined model as a whole.

  • Offensive Characteristic modifiers and Attack Attributes are applied only to the model part.

  • Rules and modifiers from a Weapon Enchantment are only applied to the Standard Melee Attacks made with the Enchanted Weapon.

Exceptions to above may be noted in the item's description, using terminology such as:

  • The wielder, wearer, bearer: These terms mean the same thing for rules purposes and refer to the model part the Magic Item was bought for, and therefore generally don't affect mounts.

  • The wielder's model, wearer's model, bearer's model: These terms refer to all model parts of the model the Magic Item was bought for, including their mounts.

  • The wielder's unit, wearer's unit, bearer's unit: affects all model parts in the same unit as the model the Magic Item was bought for, including mounts and the model itself.

*Characters on Mounts with fixed Global or Defensive Characteristics values, i.e. anything not C or C+X, do not benefit from +X modifiers to thoses Characteristics.
See Character Mounts section for examples of interactions with Mounts.

special-list_of_common_and_shared_magic_.title: List of Common and Shared Magic Items
special-list_of_common_and_shared_magic_.def: Magic Items fall into one of the following categories.

special-heros_heart.title: Hero's Heart
special-heros_heart.def: +1 Att, and always at least Str 5 and AP 2.

special-giant_slayer.title: Giant Slayer
special-giant_slayer.def: Crush Attack. This Crush Attack always hits on 4+.

special-king_slayer.title: King Slayer
special-king_slayer.def: Attached. While there is an enemy Character in contact with the wielder's unit: +1 Att, +2 Str, and +2 AP.

special-vorpal_binding.title: Vorpal Binding
special-vorpal_binding.def: Successful Armour Saves and Special Saves against attacks made with this weapon have to be rerolled.

special-destinys_call.title: Destiny's Call
special-destinys_call.def:
Aegis (4+), and the wearer's model's Arm is set to always 3.

Note that this means it cannot be improved beyond 3. It is still affected by AP.

special-essence_of_mithril.title: Essence of Mithril
special-essence_of_mithril.def: The wearer's Arm is set to 5 and can never be improved beyond this.

special-dusk_forged.title: Dusk Forged
special-dusk_forged.def: The bearer must reroll its failed Armour Saves. The bearer automatically fails any Special Save, regardless if using the Shield or not.

special-basalt_infusion.title: Basalt Infusion
special-basalt_infusion.def: +1 Arm, Aegis (3+, against Flaming Attacks), and the wearer automatically fails all Fortitude Saves.

special-wild_warding.title: Wild Warding
special-wild_warding.def: +3 Arm. The Armour Value can never be improved beyond 5.

special-banner_of_speed.title: Banner of Speed
special-banner_of_speed.def: A unit with one or more Banners of Speed gains +1" Cha and +1" Mob.

special-sheltering_standard.title: Sheltering Standard
special-sheltering_standard.def: Attacks with AP 3 or less can never reduce the Armour Save roll of the bearer's unit to worse than 6+.

special-banner_of_discipline.title: Banner of Discipline
special-banner_of_discipline.def: The bearer's unit may reroll failed Panic Tests. If the Battle Standard Bearer or the General is part of the bearer's unit, it automatically passes Panic Tests instead.

special-distortion_emblem.title: Distortion Emblem
special-distortion_emblem.def: One use only. May be activated at the start of any Phase. The bearer's unit gains Hard Target (2) until the end of the Player Turn.

special-flaming_standard.title: Flaming Standard
special-flaming_standard.def: The bearer's unit gains Flaming Attacks (Melee & Shooting).

special-aether_icon.title: Aether Icon
special-aether_icon.def: The bearer's unit gains Magic Resistance (1).

special-rending_banner.title: Rending Banner
special-rending_banner.def: One use only. May be activated at the start of a Round of Combat, when Choosing Equipment and Abilities. All models in the unit gain +1 AP until the end of combat.

special-binding_scroll.title: Binding Scroll
special-binding_scroll.def: May be activated at the end of Siphon the Veil during the enemy Magic Phase. When activated, pick an enemy model and select one of its spells, including Bound Spells. The selected model cannot cast the chosen instance of the spell during this Magic Phase. Only a single <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/binding_scroll">Binding Scroll</nuxt-link> may be activated during the same phase.

special-essence_of_a_free_mind.title: Essence of a Free Mind
special-essence_of_a_free_mind.def: The bearer may choose up to two Paths on the Army List instead of one (from the ones normally available to it). Select spells for both Paths on the Army List as normal. During Spell Selection, choose which one of the two Paths to use. The bearer cannot select Master Spells.

special-crown_of_the_wizard_king.title: Crown of the Wizard King
special-crown_of_the_wizard_king.def: During Spell Selection, randomise a Magic Path (from all Paths in this book). The bearer is a Wizard Apprentice using the randomised Path. It cannot select the Hereditary Spell. The bearer cannot take any Special Items nor any other upgrades that are restricted to Wizards (or any types of Wizards).

special-magical_heirloom.title: Magical Heirloom
special-magical_heirloom.def: The bearer knows the Hereditary Spell of its Army Book in addition to its other spells, cannot select it during Spell Selection, and cannot replace or otherwise lose it.

special-talisman_of_the_void.title: Talisman of the Void
special-talisman_of_the_void.def: Channel (1). This item can only be used if the model's army total combined Channel is 3 or less (excluding Channel from this Magic Item).

special-rod_of_battle.title: Rod of Battle
special-rod_of_battle.def: The bearer can cast Living Steel (Alchemy) as a Bound Spell (4+), with the following change: it only affects Melee Attacks.

special-dragons_brew.title: Dragon's Brew
special-dragons_brew.def: Breath Attack (Str 4, AP 1, Flaming Attacks, Stand and Shoot).

special-potion_of_str.title: Potion of Str
special-potion_of_str.def: One use only. May be activated at the start of any Round of Combat. Until the end of the Player Turn, the bearer gains Crush Attack.

special-scroll_of_power.title: Scroll of Power
special-scroll_of_power.def: May be activated when the bearer fails a Casting Roll or when you fail a Dispelling Roll, by removing 1 Magic Dice from your pool. Reroll all Magic Dice used for the Casting or Dispelling Roll.

special-spell_scroll.title: Spell Scroll
special-spell_scroll.def: May be activated at any time during your Magic Phase. The bearer knows the spell indicated in brackets (X), in addition to its other spells. If the bearer already knows the spell, this has no effect.

special-how_to_use_this_document.title: How to Use this Document
special-how_to_use_this_document.def: This document describes the different <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/paths_of_magic">Paths of Magic</nuxt-link> and Special Items available for The 9th Age: Fantasy Battles and as such is to be used in conjunction with the main Rulebook. For convenience, we repeated the main rules related to spells and Special Items from the Rulebook in the corresponding sections below, along with the information needed to read the Paths.

special-paths_of_magic.title: Paths of Magic
special-paths_of_magic.def: Spells are cast during the Magic Phase. Most spells belong to a specific Path of Magic.

special-spell_classification.title: Spell Classification
special-spell_classification.def:
Spells are categorised into one or more of the following classes:

  • Apprentice spells (C), spells from a Path of Magic, that any of its users can choose.

  • Adept spells (L), spells from a Path of Magic that Adepts and Masters can choose.

  • Master spells (M), spells from a Path of Magic that are only accessible for Masters.

  • Hereditary spells (H), spells that are unique to each Army Book.

  • Bound Spells have their own set of rules and differ from other spell classifications. Refer to the specific rules for Bound Spells.

special-spell_name.title: Spell Name
special-spell_name.def: Use the <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/spell_name">spell name</nuxt-link> to indicate which spell you want to cast.

special-casting_value.title: Casting Value
special-casting_value.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/casting_value">Casting Value</nuxt-link> is the minimum number you need to roll with Magic Dice to successfully cast the spell.

special-spell_type.title: Spell Type
special-spell_type.def:
The spell type specifies how the target of the spell is chosen. A spell can have one or more of the following spell Types.

  • Augment: Can only target friendly units, or friendly models within units if Focused.

  • Aura: Targets all eligible targets. For example, a spell with Augment, Aura, and Range 12" targets all friendly units within 12" of the Caster.

  • Caster: Can only target the model casting the spell.

  • Damage: Can only target units not Engaged in Combat.

  • Focused: Can only target single models, including Attachable Models inside units. If a model consisting of multiple model parts is targeted, only one part can be chosen.

  • Ground: The spell targets a point on the Battlefield rather than units or models.

  • Hex: Can only target enemy units, or enemy models within units if Focused.

  • Missile: Can only target units within the Caster's Line of Sight. It cannot be cast if the Caster is Engaged in Combat. When casting a spell with Type: Missile, check which is the Target Facing (see Shooting Phase chapter). If the Target Facing is the Flank Facing or the Rear Facing, any hits caused by the spell will benefit from Advantaged Position (see Attacks chapter).

  • Range X": The spell has a maximum casting range. Targets must be within X" of the Caster.

  • Universal: The spell can target both friendly and enemy units, or models within units if Focused.

special-duration.title: Duration
special-duration.def: All spells have a Duration, which follows the same rule as described under Duration of Effects, see Definitions and Terminology chapter.

special-effect.title: Effect
special-effect.def: The <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/effect">effect</nuxt-link> of a spell describes what happens to the target when the spell is successfully cast.

custom-netted.title: Netted
custom-netted.def: Units <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/netted">Netted</nuxt-link> one or more times suffer -1 Strength and -1 Armour Penetration until the end of the Round of Combat.

custom-gigantic.title: Gigantic
custom-gigantic.def: The model has Fear, Massive Bulk,  (D6), Terror, Towering Presence

custom-standard.title: Standard
custom-standard.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/standard">Standard</nuxt-link> does not grant additional Model Rules

custom-infantry.title: Infantry
custom-infantry.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/infantry">Infantry</nuxt-link> does not grant additional Model Rules

custom-cavalry.title: Cavalry
custom-cavalry.def: The model has Cannot be Stomped, Swiftstride and Tall

custom-construct.title: Construct
custom-construct.def: The model cannot use  and has Chariot

custom-close_combat_attacks.title: Close Combat Attacks
custom-close_combat_attacks.def:
Model parts perform a number of Close Combat Attacks equal to their Attack Value.
Special Attacks are considered to be Melee Attacks that are not Close Combat Attacks (see Special Attacks)

custom-eyratki.title: Eyratöki
custom-eyratki.def: The wielder gains Crush Attack, and can perform two Crush Attacks instead of one (provided it declared the use of its Crush Attack at the end of step 4 of the Round of Combat Sequence as usual).

custom-clipped_wings.title: Clipped Wings
custom-clipped_wings.def:
If Clipped Wings is stated after the X value in brackets, any unsaved wound caused by the attack against a model
with is multiplied into X+1 instead of X.

custom-guiding_piercing_spike.title: Guiding Piercing Spike
custom-guiding_piercing_spike.def: <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/close_combat_attacks">Close Combat Attacks</nuxt-link> made by the model gain +1 Armour Penetration.

custom-guiding_venom_sacs.title: Guiding Venom Sacs
custom-guiding_venom_sacs.def: The model gains Poison Attacks. If the model's Close Combat Attacks already were Poison Attacks from another source than this Manifestation, they wound automatically on a successful natural to-hit roll of '5' or '6', unless the target has Immune (Poison Attacks).

custom-guiding_digestive_vomit.title: Guiding Digestive Vomit
custom-guiding_digestive_vomit.def: The first time the model is on the winning side of a combat, it gains +1 Strength and +1 Armour Penetration until the end of the game.

custom-guiding_mirrored_scales.title: Guiding Mirrored Scales
custom-guiding_mirrored_scales.def: Each Close Combat Attack allocated towards the model for which a natural ‘1’ is rolled to hit is distributed onto the attacking model's Health Pool.

custom-guiding_unhinging_jaw.title: Guiding Unhinging Jaw
custom-guiding_unhinging_jaw.def: Failed to-wound rolls from Close Combat Attacks against Large or Gigantic models made by the model must be rerolled.

custom-guiding_smothering_coils.title: Guiding Smothering Coils
custom-guiding_smothering_coils.def: The model gains +1 to-wound with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/close_combat_attacks">Close Combat Attacks</nuxt-link> against models with Scoring.

custom-guiding_roaming_hands.title: Guiding Roaming Hands
custom-guiding_roaming_hands.def: While the unit is Engaged with an enemy unit's Flank or Rear Facing, the model gains +1 Strength and +1 Armour Penetration.

custom-guiding_hot_blood.title: Guiding Hot Blood
custom-guiding_hot_blood.def: The model gains Devastating Charge (+2 Agi).

custom-guiding_broodmother.title: Guiding Broodmother
custom-guiding_broodmother.def: For each Health Point loss the model causes with <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/close_combat_attacks">Close Combat Attacks</nuxt-link> against enemy units, roll a D6 at the end of the Initiative Step. For each rolled 6+, the model's Health Pool Raises 1 Health Point.

custom-guiding_segmented_shell.title: Guiding Segmented Shell
custom-guiding_segmented_shell.def: When the model suffers a wound from an attack with Multiple Wounds (X), reduce X by 1, to a minimum of 1.

custom-guiding_red_haze.title: Guiding Red Haze
custom-guiding_red_haze.def: The model's <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/close_combat_attacks">Close Combat Attacks</nuxt-link> gain +1 Strength and +1 Armour Penetration, but each of its <nuxt-link class="ruleLink" to="/app/rule/close_combat_attacks">Close Combat Attacks</nuxt-link> with a natural to-hit roll of ‘1’ is distributed onto the attacking model's Health Pool.

custom-combat_result_bonus.title: Combat Result Bonus
custom-combat_result_bonus.def: Adds X to the Combat Result
